intro: Neobesseya missouriensis subsp. similis, commonly known as the Missouri false indigo, is a flowering plant native to the central United States. It is a member of the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its upright growth habit and trifoliate leaves. The plant produces small, pea-like flowers that are typically blue or purple in color, blooming in late spring to early summer. It is often found in moist, well-drained soils in open woodlands and along streambanks.
